children.text: While the Democratic and Republican parties have not made climate action a priority this election season, Big Oil is on the offensive at the state level, spending big to control the narrative.
What’s at stake for Big Oil on November 8? Which key low-profile but high-stakes offices are fossil fuel companies spending on — and who are the top recipients of all those dirty funds?
In this edition of Election Insider, exclusively for supporting subscribers, we break down the big climate races and power players spending to control the climate agenda.
Five Important Gubernatorial Big Oil Recipients
On October 6, three West Coast governors and the Canadian Premier of British Columbia signed a
to make the region — which boasts
and a combined GDP of $3.5 trillion — the first area on the continent to transition to 100-percent clean electricity and a low-carbon economy.

The actions of governors, in other words, have extensive impacts on climate change, and for meaningful transformation to happen, the number of states slashing carbon emissions must grow. That cannot happen when gubernatorial elections are being won by candidates taking in vast sums of fossil fuel money, as we highlight below.

Texas to “use all lawful powers and tools to challenge any federal action that threatens the continued strength, vitality and independence of the energy industry.”

That money could have an outsized impact on the climate crisis, thanks to New Mexico’s historically weak enforcement of the fossil fuel industry, and the counterproductive consequences of Democrats’ Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). According to a recent
, the IRA has reduced certain land protections and positioned New Mexico’s unleased federal land as a prime target for the fossil fuel industry. Oil and gas production accounts for

children.text: State-level executive officers have tremendous power over environmental issues. Here’s a rundown of the fossil fuel and energy industry’s involvement in five state races that will shape how states manage energy transitions.

oversees the permitting of oil and gas projects, monitors how drilling complies with regulations, and manages pipelines and oil and gas emergency response. Christian has been an outspoken advocate for the fossil fuel industry, frequently writing op-eds in
against radical policies like the Green New Deal and Paris Climate Agreement,” and pushing
technologies, which have been called little more than a fossil fuel handout.

to disbar Paxton for filing false information in a case regarding Trump’s false claims of a stolen election, and such legal troubles have placed him in what is now a

natural disaster relief funding, including billions of dollars Congress appropriated to Texas after Hurricane Harvey in 2017. On her
, however, Buckingham says she will “unleash Texas energy and fight the Green New Deal.”
is running for re-election to the Louisiana Public Service Commission — an agency that regulates utilities — and has taken

from energy companies. Public utility commissioners, broadly speaking, act as gatekeepers to clean energy and have tremendous control over how and whether states make just and green transitions away from fossil fuels. Only 11 states elect their commissioners, and because these races typically fly under the radar, donations have a big impact. Last month, Francis, a Republican,
backlash from Louisianans over high electric bills charged by the for-profit, investor-owned electric utility Cleco. Francis has
as much as $9,000 in donations from Cleco coffers, and he has argued that lowering the electricity bills would
pulling money out of shareholders’ pockets.
, a Democrat, is running for re-election for a fourth six-year term to the Louisiana Public Service Commission and has taken
from energy firms like Atmos, Cleco, and Valero — companies he is supposed to be regulating. Boisseiere’s
